subNodes.conversationText: It was midday, and the sun was high and hot. Everything seemed indolent -- the birds took shorter flights, the insects zoomed in slower circles, plants drooped.
All of a sudden, a portal materialized in front of <FirstName>.
<He/She> prepared <him/her>self for battle, but instead of a grim usher and another hostile throng from the Roots of the World, out stepped a shy, kindly-looking being.
She said nothing. She put both hands into the portal and with great effort pulled out a sack three times as big as she was.

She opened it and drew forth dazzling, rich jewels -- carbuncles, diamonds, and sapphires.

Then she tossed the small hoard into the air. The carbuncles turned into orange pebbles, the diamonds into dandelion seeds, and the sapphires into rain.
She smiled faintly and motioned for <FirstName> to look inside the sack.
"Who are you? How did you find me?"
She shook her head and held her finger to her lips.
The young witch examined her wares.
The young witch examined her wares.
The young witch examined her wares.
The young witch examined her wares.
The young witch examined her wares.
The young witch examined her wares.
The young witch examined her wares.
The young witch examined her wares.
The young witch examined her wares.
The young witch examined her wares.
The young witch examined her wares.
The young witch examined her wares.

actions.a_parameter_1: You have met Sieben, the game's only merchant. Sieben appears around the same time every day. She sells things for dross, a metaphysical substance the young witch gets after each encounter with the Congress of Moths. Her stock may vary; if you see something you want, act fast. Your Charisma score affects prices for buying and selling.

subNodes.conversationText: The second day's adventures were well under way when another portal appeared.
Sieben stepped out, her sack slung over her shoulder. She waved, and the young witch looked inside.
A partly cloudy morning gave way to a sunny late summer afternoon. Just as the day was brightening, Sieben materialized with her sack of goods.
She took a monocle from her bag and put it on, frowning and pursing her lips. Then she laughed, tossed it back in, and showed <FirstName> what she'd brought.
<FirstName> heard a noise in the underbrush.
An animal? A bird? Something more sinister?
To <his/her> surprise, Sieben stepped out. No portal this time, and she had no sack. Instead, she held up a mound of woodland flowers and fruits. Were these made of dross, too?

Out of nowhere, a white pony sprang into <FirstName> 's path, a diminutive knight astride it. Silver bells tinkled on the animal's harness, and the knight's sabatons just barely rested in silver spurs. The pony's eyes were as green as emeralds
The knight lifted her visor. It was Sieben.
She opened a saddlebag fastened with a silver clasp and invited <FirstName> to look at the treasures within.
"At this time tomorrow..." the young witch thought.

As <he/she> was thinking, Sieben appeared wearing a green cap with a black feather stuck in it.

She opened her bag, but instead of revealing its contents to <FirstName>, she held it up to Pharaoh and Knott.
Only then did <he/she> show her goods to <FirstName>.

To anybody else, it would have seemed like an ordinary day, if a little cool for August. The season of decline was waiting in the wings, ready for his yearly tragedy. The young witch felt as if <he/she> were about to take the stage too -- but with less confidence than autumn, and no clear idea what came after.
<He/She> felt <his/her> insides turn upsde-down. The world went quiet, and <he/she> stumbled. <He/She> seemed to be falling backward in a black tunnel.
<He/She> emerged from it close to the tree that had been Malkin. Eldest Lady and Middle One were opposite, between <him/her> and the tree, standing in a circle of rocks they'd placed on the ground.

The crimson grass was wilting, and the blue flowers drooped. The leaves of the lone tree were falling. Eldest Lady and Middle One stooped in the grass, squinting in the sunlight. A cloth lay over a heap of something on the ground in the middle of the circle, next to the tree.

The crimson grass was wilting, and the blue flowers drooped. The leaves of the lone tree were falling. Eldest Lady and Middle One stooped in the grass, squinting in the sunlight. They stood next to tree, near the middle of the circle.

<He/She> emerged from it standing close to the tree the woodcutter's boy had shown <him/her>. Eldest Lady and Middle One were opposite, between <him/her> and the tree, standing in a circle of rocks they'd placed on the ground.

<He/She> emerged from it standing on a little hill amidst a thicket of ilex. Eldest Lady and Middle One were opposite, between <him/her> and a lone tree, standing in a circle of rocks they'd placed on the ground.

Around the tree grew red grass and blue flowers the likes of which <FirstName> had never seen before.
